c - xss vuln.description: A security researcher responsibly disclosed a reflected XSS in your platform that could impact privileged users.

choices.description: Thank the researcher and carry on.
choices.impact: On a CVSS scale, this rated as a CVSS 2. It's nearly impossible to exploit and has no confidentiality or integrity impact. It has a low availability impact. You lucked out.

choices.description: Tell the engineering team that owns this area that this is a drop everything. Needs to be fixed ASAP.
choices.impact: The CTO is fed up with all your drop everything requests and gives the CEO an ultimatum: Either you're fired or they quit.

d - outsourced engineering.description: It's a challenging software engineering hiring market. The CTO wants to bring in globally sourced software engineering contractors with BYOD devices.

choices.description: The the CTO absolutely not. You don't have the necessary secure access solutions in place and you don't have the budget or capcity to implement.
You don't want to upset the CTO, so you go along with "trying" it.
choices.impact: It turns out one of the contractors hired was really a North Korean nation state hacker who promptly encrypts all company data for a ransom.

e - privacy ops.description: Legal is asking for your help establishing a data deletion capability to meet California regulatory requirements.

choices.description: Tell them this isn't a security issue and even if it was, you're already behind on the projects to you comitted to.
choices.impact: Legal isn't happy with your response, but ultimately agrees and will work with the customer service department to find a solution.

choices.description: Agree and select a security project to put on the back burner.
choices.impact: This choice impacts work related to reaching SOX compliance and now the CEO isn't happy because IPO readiness dates are slipping.

b - unpatched servers.description: Engineering is falling behind on patching their EC2 instances based on CTO guidance to focus on shipping features.

choices.description: Do nothing. It's not worth upsetting the CTO and maybe the CEO.
choices.impact: All of your data has been encrypted by a ransomware bot that exploited common vulnerabilities.

choices.description: Give the CTO an ultimatum: Patch or EC2 instances behind on 30 days of critical patches will be shut down.
choices.impact: The CTO grumbles, but agrees to keep up with all critical patches installed within 90 days of release and/or it's a drop everything patch event at your direction (ie Log4J like event).

a - exposed s3 bucket.description: Your team has recieved an email from a proton address suggesting you have an exposed S3 bucket. All objects in the bucket are accessible via anonymous requests.

choices.description: Do nothing. We get reports like this. It's mostly security researchers looking for an easy reward.
choices.impact: It turns out there was customer data in that bucket that led to a breach and a total cost of $9 million for the company, and there was no budget to cover.

choices.description: Stop everything and review, but it _could_ impact both your project deliverable and/or other team's project/product delivarables.
choices.impact: The bucket had static website data (images, javascript, etc) for a public site. Nothing to worry about

Jetson Robot.description: Jetson Robot. An exciting startup that is uber-izing at home laundry tasks.
firstDayPrompts: Welcome to Jetson Robot, we're so excited to have you.
We operate a online marketplace to hire gig workers to come into your home and do laundry for you.
There's a new competitor that's starting up. It's very important we outpace their ability to ship marketplace features.
Your highest priorities this year are to:
1. Reduce friction points related to customer security questionaires
2. Make sure we're IPO ready.
3. The board wants to make sure "we're secure".
Some things about Jetson Robot that should help you invest your budget:
* We are cloud native and run everything in AWS
* Our coding language of choice is Go
* We currently have 100 customers
* We currently have 10 engineering and 50 non-engineering employees.
* We prefer SAAS over open source solutions.

Open Sesame.description: Open Sesame. An exciting startup using AI to help employees navigate the maze of access requests.
firstDayPrompts: Open Sesame, we're so excited to have you.
We're developing a LLM based AI solution that will significantly reduce friction related to employee access requests.
The platform will integrate with all the popular Identity & SSO solutions.
Your highest priorities this year are to:
1. Our CTO wants to make sure "we're building security in".
2. Our CEO wants to eliminate any blockers related to security.
Some things about Open Sesame. that should help you invest your budget:
* We are cloud native and run everything in GCP
* Our coding language of choice is Rust
* We currently have 5 customers
* We currently have 50 engineering and 10 non-engineering employees.
* We prefer SAAS over open source solutions.

Bug Bounty.description: Bug Bounty on a bug bounty platform - $50,000

SAST Scanner.description: Purchase a SAAS based SAST scanner solution. $30/engineer

Cloud Security Posture Management.description: Purchase a Cloud Security Posture Management SAAS solution. $200,000

SSO.description: A SSO/IDP solution. $75 per internal user (employee/contractor/etc).

CASB.description: A cloud access security broker solution - $20/computer.

Secure Access Solution.description: A secure access solution that enables zero trust - $50/computer.

Device Management.description: Device Management to force secure configs on all endpoint devices - $50/computer.

Trust Center Platform.description: Purchase and implement a trust portal SAAS service. $20,000

Vendor Risk Management.description: SAAS based vendor risk management solution. $90,000

policies.description: Creating and sharing cyber security policies. $0

SOC 2 Type 1 - Security Trust Service Cr.description: Achieve SOC 2 Type 1 in the security trust service criteria. $150,000

SEIM.description: Purchase a SAAS based SEIM solution. $50,000

Public Privacy Policy.description: Work with legal to create and publish a privacy policy on all public sites. $0

Privacy Consultation.description: Hire a consulting firm to review your business, applicable regulatory (GDPR/CCPA) requirements, and privacy operations - $100,000
